subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Unicode proposal again.

messageBody:
I agree with Michael on the second point.

The differences between Junior/Senior Quikscript belong in the rendering
layer along with things like the typeface, colour, 3D effects and so on.
The Unicode specification is only about the logical layer stuff - how
the words are spelt and so on.

I do think we should have a semi-official/standard way of overriding the
choices the rendering layer makes though.
Especially since we don't actually _have_ a rendering layer yet.
It's going to take some serious thought/kludging to put a Senior
Quikscript font together and it would be very useful to have a method of
creating test strings with a rendering we can fix.
Sort of a before/after or a
this-is-what-we-want-it-to-look-like-when-we-get-the-fonts-working.

Luckily Unicode already has just the thing - Variant Selectors.

I say we go with the following:

Any Quikscript Letter followed by Variant Selector 1 is rendered as it
would be in Junior Quikscript, i.e. full height, normal orientation.
A Quikscript Letter followed by Variant Selector 2 is rendered in it's
alternate form (if any), i.e. half height or inverted.
A Quikscript Letter on it's own would be handled by the rendering layer
as normal.

This would be useful stop gap 'scaffolding' for putting together some
smart fonts.
It doesn't belong in our Unicode proposal though.

Michael Everson wrote:
>
> At 01:37 -0400 2007-05-29, Ph.D. wrote:
> >I've been very busy lately, and I don't have time to look into this
> >right now, but my first impression is that unifying Quikscript with
> >Shavian makes the
> >same mistake originally made in unifying Coptic with Greek.
>
> Except that Quikscript is a revision of Shavian made by the deviser of
> Shavian.
>
> >And would we need two different encodings for some characters so as
> >to have a regular character and a combining character for Junior
> >versus Senior Quikscript?
>
> Most certainly not that. You might have ligatures in your font but
> turn them on or off.
>
> --
> Michael Everson * http://www.evertype.com <http://www.evertype.com>
>
>
